questions.question: It the study of the interaction between people and computers.
Is is a multidisciplinary field that draws knowledge and methods from various discipline to understand and improve the interaction between humans and computers.
(1945)Vennevar Bush describes a ________, which is a precursor to hypertext.
(1962)Douglas Engelbert introduces this concept ________.
(1968)Ivan Sutherland develops ________, one of the first graphical user interfaces.
(1973)Xerox PARC develops the ________, which features a graphical user interface similar to the Macintosh.
(1984)The ________ is released, popularizing the use of graphical user interfaces.
(1993)The ________ is created, which makes it possible for people to interact with computer over the internet.
(2007)The ________ was released, which popularized the use of touchscreens.
(2011)The first commercial augmented reality(AR) headset was ________.
Refers to the ease with which a user can interact with a system or product to achieve their goals. A system or product is considered usable if it is intuitive, efficient, and user-friendly.

Encompasses the overall feelings, perceptions, and responses of a user when interacting with a product or system. It includes aspects like satisfaction, enjoyment, efficiency, and effectiveness of the interaction.

Concerned with making technology and digital content usable by individuals with disabilities. This includes ensuring that people with various impairments can perceive, understand, navigate, and interact with digital systems.

Ensuring that a system or product is free from errors, crashes, and security vulnerabilities. Users should feel confident that the technology will perform as expected without harming them or their data.
Refers to the system's ability to accomplish tasks quickly and with minimal effort on the part of the user. It involves how well a system or product performs its intended functions.
Refer to a system's ability to adapt to different user needs or changing circumstances. An adaptable and flexible system can be customized to suit different user preferences and requirements.

They involve addressing the ethical implications of technology use and its impact on society. This includes issues like data privacy, security, bias, and the broader societal implications of technology.

enumeration.question: Enumerate the Primary Goal of HCI

questions.question: Involves the study of human behavior, cognition, and emotions as they relate to the use of technology. Psychologists in HCI research areas like user behavior, perception, decision-making, and user motivation to inform design and user experience.

Provides the technical foundation for HCI. It encompasses the development of software, hardware, and systems that facilitate human-computer interaction. Computer scientists in HCI work on creating technology that is efficient, functional, and user-friendly.

Refers to the process of creating user interfaces and overall user experiences. Designers focus on the visual and interaction aspects of software and hardware to ensure that they are aesthetically pleasing and easy to use.
This field focuses on designing technology to fit human capabilities, limitations, and comforts.

Concerned with the study of human cognition, including memory, attention, problem-solving, and decision-making. HCI researchers draw from cognitive science to understand how users process information and make decisions when interacting with technology.
Involves the management and organization of information, data, and knowledge. In HCI, it's important for designing systems that present information in a structured and understandable manner.

Brings a cultural and social perspective to HCI. Researchers in these fields study how technology is adopted and used in different cultural and social contexts, considering factors like values, norms, and societal impact.

Understanding how language and communication play a role in user interfaces, voice recognition, and natural language processing. It helps in designing interfaces that effectively interpret and generate human language.

Is a research method used in HCI to observe and understand how people use technology in their natural environments. It involves immersive field studies to gain insights into user behaviors, needs, and contexts.

enumeration.question: Enumerate the Disciplines Contributing to HCI

questions.question: Involves creating interfaces and systems that are intuitive, easy to use, and enjoyable for users. It focuses on designing with the user's needs and preferences in mind, minimizing the learning curve, and providing a positive user experience.
It involves designing interfaces that prevent users from making mistakes, providing clear feedback, and guiding users to achieve their goals without undue frustration.

Refers to designing computer systems and interfaces that align with the way users naturally work and interact in their everyday lives. It aims to make technology relevant and practical, ensuring that users can easily integrate it into their existing routines and tasks.

Integrating HCI considerations into the design process means involving HCI experts and usability testing throughout the development cycle. This ensures that usability and user experience factors are considered from the initial design stages and continue to be addressed throughout the development process.

Dealing with sensitive data or applications that may pose risks to users. It involves adhering to regulations, standards, and guidelines to protect user data, ensure product safety, and meet legal obligations in various domains.
The one whom computer system are designed to assist. THe Requirements of the user should therefore be our first priority.
Is a model of human information processing.
A type of memory that stores information from the senses for a very short period of time.
Information from sensory memory is transferred to short-term memory through.
Is a temporary storage system that holds information that is currently being used.
Information from short-term memory can be transfered to long-term memory through.
It the part of the memory that stores information for a long period of time.
The first step of how our memory stores information.
When you give an attention into information, that information will now store in to.
We need this so we can store this information in to long-term memory
It is the inability to acces information from our memory.

You are storing or putting information to your memory.
Refers to the system responsible for encoding, storing, and retrieving personal experiences and specific events or episodes in your life.

It involves the storage of factual knowledge, concepts, and information that are not tied to specific personal experiences. This type of memory encompasses a wide range of information, such as facts, concepts, language, and general knowledge about the world.
Also known as Working Memory.

enumeration.question: The three main components of the user as an information processing system.

questions.question: Head (Output to Input)
Eyes (Output to Input)
Facial Muscles (Output to Input)

Hands and Fingers (Output to Input)
Feet and Legs (Output to Input)
This component represents how humans gather information from the environment. It involves sensory processes such as vision, hearing, touch, and other senses.
It is responsible for executing physical actions in response to the information processed by the cognitive system.

It is responsible for tasks such as memory, attention, problem-solving, decision-making, and language processing. It processes the information received from the perceptual system and generates actions based on that information.
refers to the sensory memory associated with visual information. It is extremely short-lived, lasting only for a fraction of a second (typically less than a second).
the sensory memory associated with auditory information, such as sounds and spoken language. It lasts longer than iconic memory, typically around 2 to 4 seconds
This sensory information helps you recognize objects, navigate your environment, and perform various tactile tasks.
Using knowledge to draw conclusion or infer new information.
Derives a logically necessary conclusion from given premises, even if it doesn't always align with our notion of truth.
Generalized from observed cases to infer information about unobserved cases, although it may not be entirely reliable.
Reasons from a fact to the cause of the fact, helping us derive explanations for observed events.
It is process of finding a solution to an unfamiliar task using the knowledge we have.
In this theory, you are deviding or restructuring the problem and gaining insight to find innovattive solutions.
We called it a trial and error theory.
Refers to the process of gaining experties and proficiency in a particular domain over time. It is a complex process that involves a number of factors.
It is a factor in skill acquisition that said, you are gaining skill through teaching

Refers to the repetitive and purposeful engagement in a specific task or activity to improve one's skills and proficiency. In HCI, this can involve practicing user interface design, interaction techniques, or other aspects of human-computer interaction.

Involves receiving information about the quality and effectiveness of one's actions or interactions with a computer system. This information can be in the form of user testing results, usability evaluations, or direct user feedback.

Refers to the theoretical understanding and knowledge of principles, concepts, and models that underlie HCI. This knowledge can include human cognition, user experience (UX) design principles, information architecture, and various HCI models.
Refers to the awareness and understanding of one's cognitive processes, including the ability to monitor, control, and optimize one's learning and problem-solving strategies.
Are unintentional actions that devirate from the desired outcome. They can range from minor inconveniences to serious consequences.

This model is widely used in the field of Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) and user experience (UX) design to understand how users interact with systems and how design can influence the user experience.
This model emphasizes that the user experience goes beyond usability and functionality, considering the emotional and hedonic aspects of user interactions.

enumeration.question: Kinds of Interaction and User Experience

questions.question: A step-by-step approach followed to create user-centered experience and prototypes, from unnderstanding user needs to evaluating the final design.
A well-defined process provides a clear path for designing and evaluating user interfaces, ensuring that all relevant aspects are considered.
A process helps in systematically identifying user needs, conducting research, prototyping, testing, and iterating, leading to more effective HCI solutions.
Following a consistent process promotes reliability in design outcomes, making it easier to replicate successful designs and avoid errors.
A process can serve as a framework for both newcomers and experienced professionals, helping them understand and teach HCI principles and methods.
Having a standardized process fosters a common understanding among team members, facilitating collaboration and communication in HCI projects.
It is cycle that emcompasses the process of designing a user experience, starting from ideation to deployment and beyond.
It is a depiction of how the activities of the lifecycle are organized and arrange in chronological.
It is a structured framework that guides the process of designing a user experience.
These are the essential tasks and steps that are performed during the process of creating a user experience.
These are the different approaches used to carry out the main activities or subactivities in the user experience design process.
These are specific, detailed practices used to perform individual steps within the activities, subactivities, or methods of the user experience design process.
Specific tasks and actions performed within each main activity if the user experience design process.

enumeration.question: The Basic Process Components for UX

questions.question: Involves keenly and objectively watching people, events, or situations to gather information and insights.
Is the process of simplifying complex information or concepts into more manageable and understandable forms.
Involves recording important information, ideas, or observations for future reference or organization.
Is the skill of structuring and categorizing information logically and efficiently.
entails creating representations or visualizations of objects, systems, or processes to understand them better.
is the art of conveying information, ideas, or experiences through narratives that engage and captivate an audience.
involves fully engaging in an experience or environment to gain a deep understanding of it.
is a creative technique for generating a wide range of ideas and solutions within a group.
involve visually representing ideas, concepts, or designs through hand-drawn images.
is the way in which a problem or situation is presented, and involves looking at it from different perspectives.
is the ability to form logical conclusions, and involves drawing specific conclusions from general information.
is the creation of preliminary models or representations of a design or idea, and involves imagining future scenarios.
involves analyzing and evaluating information or arguments.
Refers to the process of refining and improving a design through multiple cycles or rounds of evaluation, feedback, and revision.

enumeration.question: UX Design Techniques as Life Skills

questions.question: This activity involves gaining insights into users, their work practices, usage patterns, and the subject-matter domain to understand their needs and requirements for the design.
In this activity, designer create designs as solutions to address the identified user needs and challenges.
Designers build prototypes of promising design solutions to visualize and test their effectiveness.
This activity involves verifying and refining the designs based on user feedback and insight to ensure a positive user experience.
This involves interviewing and observing users while they work to gather data about their practices, preference, and needs.
The collected usage research data is distilled and organized for better comprehension.
Representation are created to capture user characteristics, information, flow, tasks, and work environments. These model aid collaboration, sharing, archival, rehearsal, and immersion.
This subacitivity invloves codifying the needs and requirements identified during the reseach process.
In This sub-activity, designers engage in ideation and sketching to create various design ideas.
This sub-activity involves creating mental models, system models, and storyboards to flesh out the design concepts.
This sub-activity focuses on specifying detailed plans for implementing the selected design.
In this place, desingers develop ecological, interaction, and emotional design plans for the most promising candidates.
DEsigners develop hand-drawn or printed paper prototypes to explore and visualize design concepts in low fidelity.
Designers create basic visual representations of the user interface and interaction flow.
Desingers create interactive prototypes that allow users to navigate through the design with clickable elements, providing a more dynamic representation of the user experience.
For physical products or tangible interactions, designers create physical prototyes to test and evaluate the designs functionality and usability.

Desingers use various methods, such as user testing, surveys, or analysis, to gather data on how users interact with the design. This data provides valuable insights into user behavior and preferences.
The collected daya is analyzed to identify patterns, official incidents, and root causes. This analysis helps designers understand the strengths and weakness of the design.
Based on the evaluation results, designers propose changes and improvements to address identified issues and enhance the user experience.

The evaluation findings and proposed redesign solution solution are documented and communicated to stakeholders and the design team. This ensures everyone knows the evaluation outcomes and the design team. This ensures everyone knows the evaluation outcomes and the next steps for refining the design.
From the Latin communicare, meaning to share is the act of conveying meanings from one entity or group to another using mutually understood signs, symbols, and semiotic rules. By?
The imparting or exchanging of information by speaking, writing, or using some other medium. The successful conveying or sharing of ideas and feelings. By?
A common understanding of something. By?
The simultaneous sharing and creating of meaning through human symbolic interaction. By?
A systematic process in which individuals interact with and through symbols to create and interpret meanings. By?
Is a process of creating and sharing meaning by using verbal and nonverbal symbols in varied contexts.
It is further subdivided into written communication and oral communication.
Can involve anything from words on a page to emails, to text messages.
Involves spoken words. This can be done in person, through the phone, or over video chat.
Occurs when meaning or messages are sent or received without the use of words. It can be intentional or unintentional.
Can be displayed through body language, facial expressions, touch, or eye contact.
Utilizes drawings, illustrations, pictures, colors, graphs, charts, and signs to share meaning. It can be used in conjunction with verbal communication, or it can stand on its own.
Sender of the message. Know exactly what information to give or share.
The information you want to convey. Details of the information should be very clear.
The mental process of converting your ideas or thoughts into verbal and or nonverbal symbols that can be understood by the receiver of the message.
The way the message or information is conveyed. It may be in the form of a face-to-face conversation, text message, phone call, video conference, letter, email, reports, memo)
The receivers mental process of the message into the meaning suggested by the verbal and or nonverbal symbols used by the sender.
The people or group of people who will get the message.
The receivers response or reply to the message.
The situation in which the communication takes place.
(who the source is)
(what idea is being communicated)
(through what medium the message is relayed)
(to whom is the message directed)
(what the desired result of the communication is)
Also call the transmission model, it assumes that communication is transmitted in a straightforward manner-from a sender to a receiver. This clearly reflects that communication is a one-way process.

In this model, communication is a two-way process which involves an exchange or an interaction between the sender and the receiver. This indicates that the receiver is not just a mere absorber of the message from the receiver.

This is a model in which people interact with and through symbols overtime to share and create meaning. It has time element which influences how people communicate. Itdepicts communication as varying and dynamic. that communication occurs within systems that influence what and how people communicate. the model does not label one as sender and the receiver, instead, are communicators
Is a communication which happens within ones self. Here both Source (sender) and receiver is only one. so, the feedback works without any interruption.

The process of exchange of information, ideas and feelings between two or more people through verbal or non-verbal methods. It often includes face-to-face exchange of information, in a form of voice, facial expressions, body language and gestures.
Two persons are involved in this communication process. Here the source becomes a receiver and receiver becomes source.

More than two members involved in communication process will become a group communication. If least number of persons is involved in the group communication. In this communication process, everyone becomes a Source as well as receiver through sharing information and gives feedback to another.
Source or messages from a single person will reach or will be received by huge number of audiences. Feedback is quite distant because of the large number of receivers.

Basically have many audiences and they cant be grouped together in one place so a certain tool or technology for communication process is needed. But, there is no direct access with the receivers so there is a need for the use of media like newspaper, radio, television, and internet. Here the audience feedback is very less or delayed.

The Latin prefix intra- means within or inside. This communication then means talking to oneself. Some label it as self or inner talk, inner monologue, or inner dialogue. Psychologists call it with other names such as self-verbalization or self-statement.

The Latin prefix inter- means between, among and together. An interactive exchange takes place as this communication takes place. However, as it occurs, a transaction does not necessarily take place since it can only be a simple interaction such as greetings, getting to know a person, or ordinary conversations that happen between and among the interactants. This may occur in dyads or small groups, also known as group communication.

Involves the use of electronic media. With electronic media, messages are transmitted quickly, your own thinking, behavior and attitude may be influenced by the views you hear. It is important then that you weigh what you hear and assess them against those beliefs that you hold onto, so you do not get easily swayed by other peoples convictions.

The focus is on the role that communication plays in organizational contexts. Organizations comprise individuals who work for the company. For an organization to be successful, a system of communication should be put in place. A set of rules or standards for communication protocol should be made clear so that interaction patterns are established.
Allows communication to take place via designated channels of message flow between positions in the organization.
Is the type that flows from upper to lower positions. The flow of communication is top down or from a superior to a subordinate, usually asking certain individuals to perform a certain task.
Is bottom- up in which subordinates send communication to their superiors bearing their views on organizational policies, issued related to their jobs, and the like.
Is lateral in approach as it takes place among people belonging to the same level but coming from different departments or units to facilitate performance to task through proper coordination.
Is diagonal in nature as employees from different units or departments working at various levels.

Comes from unofficial channels of message flow. Also known as grapevine messages coming from the different levels of the organization. This occurs due to the dissatisfaction of some employees accompanied by uncertainty.
It is a communication between or among people having different linguistic, religious, ethnic, social, and professional backgrounds. This particularly happens with non-verbal communication.
Employs formal language delivered orally or in written form.
It involves personal and ordinary conversations with friends, family members, or acquaintances about anything under the sun. the purpose is simply to socialize and enhance relationship.

enumeration.question: Types of Communication According to Context

questions.question: Refer to rules provided by an external source, e.g., codes of conduct in workplaces or principles in religions.
Refer to an individuals own principles regarding right and wrong.
Pay attention to the needs of others, as well as yours.
Do not cause another persons embarrassment or a loss dignity.
Ensure that others have accurate information. Tell them everything they have a right and need to know, not just what is true.
Never bolster the impact of your communication by preventing people from communicating with one another or by hindering access to the supporting information.
Be responsible and accountable for the consequences of your relationships and communication.

As audience or receiver of the information, you also have ethical responsibilities. A good rule of thumb is the 100% rule, where both the sender and the receiver have full or 100% responsibility to ensure that the message is understood, and that ethics are followed.

As either sender or receiver of information, remember that your own point of view may not be shared by others and that your conclusions are relative to your perspective, so allow others to respectfully disagree or see it differently.
Be sure that the end goal of your communication and the means of getting to that end are both ethical although no rule can be applied without reservation to any situation.
In situations where you have more power than others (e.g., a teacher with a student, a boss with a subordinate, a parent with a child), you also have more responsibility for the outcome.
Balance your rights against your responsibilities even if you live in a wonderful society where your rights are protected by law; not everything you have a right to do is ethical.
Which is who you are, and what you as sender or receiver bring to the interaction--your needs, desires, values, beliefs, personality, and so on.
Which concerns your reactions to the other person based on relationship-as boss, colleague, friend, sibling. parent, and the like.

Which deals with the psycho-social where you are communicating. An interaction that takes place in a classroom, which quite formal, will be very different from one that takes place in a bar, which is very informal where communicators do not need to be guarded in their speech.
Which has to do with the physical where you are communicating-objects in the room and their arrangement, location, noise level, temperature, season, time of day.
Which includes all the learned behaviors and rules that affect the interaction. For instance, bodily movement, facial expression, gesture, distance, and eye contact vary in different cultures.

questions.question: Mobile communication is so powerful that it changes not only what we do so, but also what we are. Wherever we are, our mobile phones are also there-we are inseparable. At the dinner table with our families, in a meeting at work, during interactions in the classroom, while shopping in malls, in conversations with friends, while listening to presentations in lectures-everywhere, even at the most unlikely places like funerals--the cell phone takes us away from the people around us. It literally isolates us from the rest of the world... from humanity.

Millions of people find solace in virtual communities where they have found a second life. You might have heard of Sim City, Farmville, and Cities Skylines. In these social networking sites, users or players create or choose avatars to interact with other users anywhere in the world.

enumeration.question: Factors that affect the flow of communication.

questions.question: It is probably the most important element in the communication chain. To put it simply, it is the medium through which the group speaking that language expresses its culture.
Often misunderstandings crop up from ethnic differences. These misunderstandings in turn hamper the communication chain.
The concept of nationhood is a very complicated proposition. The concept of national pride at times inundates other humane considerations.

History has been witnessed to the fact that this has played the role of the biggest human divisive force. If we take a sneak peek into the history of humanity, we would be able to find out that religion has been the single largest cause of conflicts.

No wonder that social positioning and economic status of people put them into certain brackets. This artificial division again creates rifts between the haves and have-nots thereby leading to a breakage in the communication chain.

As basic as it is, the reality remains that this can also become an impediment for the flow of communication at times. The difference between this across the world is very real. In India, the transgender community must face social ostracism all the time. The communication channel in this case is broken. There is hardly any discourse on the community. The best way to deal with this stalemate is to accept that this cant be the basis of any discrimination. However, like many other things, it is easier said than done.

Across societies, generational shifts can cause a lot of miscommunications. As the world changes, meanings and communication channels change. At times, older people cant cope with these changes, which in turn creates an imbalance in communication. At other times, the younger generation fails to understand the frame of reference of the older people thereby creating an unnecessary rift.

This is the most basic functional block of social media. It represents the extent to which users reveal their identities in a social media setting and can include information like name, age, gender, profession, location, and also information that portrays users in certain ways.

How do users communicate with other users in a social media setting? These happen for variety of reasons such as to meet like-minded people, to find love, to build their self-esteem, or to be news-breakers on innovative ideas or trending topics.
Social often implies an exchange between people. We now distribute and receive more content in less time than all of humanity has done previously.

Have you ever checked Facebook or Foursquare to find out where your friends are? It refers to the accessibility of which you can know where others are, virtually and or physically, through status updates or check-ins. This social media building block has benefited from the world's hyper-connectivity and bridged the gap between virtual and physical.

It represents a connection between more than one user through conversation, sharing information, meeting up, or just listing each other as a follower or friend. Consequently, this can lead to duping, such as catfishing. Everything has its evils.
Can have different meanings on social media platforms, but at its core it's a sense of identifying the status of others and yourself in a social network. The study states that 'is a matter of trust'.

What communities and sub-communities exist on a social media platform, and how easy are they to construct? As your network becomes bigger with friends, followers, and contacts, it becomes necessary to sort your cronies into different groups. This is exemplified in Twitter's lists and Facebook's public, private, and secret groups.
The extent to which users know if others are available.
The extent to which users relate to each other
The extent to which users know the social standing of others and content
The extent to which users are ordered or form communications
The extent to which users communicate with each other
The extent to which users exchange, distribute and receive content
The extent to which users reveal themselves
Try not to message all your customers asking them to buy your products and avoid sharing constant advertisements on your page. Make your social profiles a blend of promotional and valuable content.
While scheduling your posts in advance and automating analytics is helpful, dont automate everything. Some things still need a human touch.
Avoid using too many hashtags at once. Even on Instagram, where you can use 30 hashtags in a single caption, its important not to overdo it.
Dont be petty. Saying negative things about your competitors online will harm your reputation more than it hurts theirs.
Dont try to be something youre not. Remember that your customers can learn whatever they need to know about your brand online today and things like authenticity can go a long way
The learned and shared behavior of a community of interacting human beings.
It is the act of conveying meanings from one entity or group to another using mutually understood signs, symbols, and semiotic rules.
Refers to the communication between people from two different cultures.
Is the mutual creation of meaning.
Is the coordination of meaning and action in a group.
Is the mutual creation of meaning across cultures.

enumeration.question: Dimensions that describe differences in national cultures

questions.question: Is the degree to which people accept an unequal distribution of power and status privileges. In this countries, there is respect for age and titles, people are expected to follow rules, and there is more tolerance for concentrated power. India, Mexico, and the Philippines have high power distance. The United States, Australia, and Israel have low power distance.

The degree to which people are uncomfortable with risk, change, and ambiguity. In high uncertainty avoidance countries, there is a greater emphasis on rules, structure, order, and predictability. France, Japan, and Costa Rica, for example, are countries with high uncertainty avoidance. The United States, India, and Sweden have low uncertainty avoidance.

Is the degree to which innovation, high standards, and excellent performance are encouraged and rewarded. Countries with high this value materialism and competitiveness, and they expect to invest in training to promote performance improvements.

Is the degree to which individuals are forceful, confrontational, and aggressive, as opposed to cooperative and compassionate. In this countries such as the United States, Germany, and Mexico, communication is direct and unambiguous. Individual initiative is encouraged, and relationships are likely to be competitive.

The degree to which delayed gratification and planning for the future are valued over short-term gains. Countries with high this encourage investments for future payoffs over immediate consumption. It is like the ability of individuals to delay gratification.

The degree to which fairness, altruism, generosity, and kindness are encouraged and valued. In nations with high this orientation, individuals are responsible for promoting the well-being of others as opposed to the state providing social and economic support.

Is the degree to which organizational and societal institutions encourage individuals to be integrated into groups and organizations. In this countries, collective distribution of resources and collective action are encouraged.

Is the degree to which individuals express pride, loyalty, and cohesiveness in their organizations or families. In countries with this, individuals identify with their families or organizations and duties and obligations determine behaviors
The degree to which male and female equality is actualized. Countries with this provide more opportunities for women and have more women in positions of power.

Includes body type, height, weight, hair, and skin color. These characteristics affect our daily communications with others. We also wear clothing, and we display artifacts, which are ornaments or adornments that themselves communicate. Our clothing and artifacts mark our unique or co-cultural identity, or the many smaller cultural groups to which we belong within a larger culture. Whatever you wear or don't wear, this says something about you.

Or vocal cues, also mark our cultural, ethnic, and gender identity. This is how we say something, not what we way. If you raise your voice during a conversation, chances are that will be interpreted as you are angry or irritated.

Falls under a larger category of nonverbal communication, kinesics, or body movement. The face can produce 250,000 different expressions. Many of these vary cross-culturally, but some can be recognized across cultures.

Is a very powerful communication tool. Holding it can be a sign of respect, truthfulness, attraction, attention, or domination and power, for example. Failure to make eye contact can similarly be an indication of respect, fear, intimidation, lack of interest, and more. Some of this depends on the culture.
Another form of kinesics, are culturally specific.
Gestures shat substitute for words and phrases, such as raising your shoulders for 'I don't know'.
Help illustrate what we are trying to say, perhaps by indicating 'this big'.
Are used to control, maintain, or 'regulate' the pace and flow of conversation, such as putting up your forefinger to indicate you're not finished speaking;
Are habits or gestures that fulfill some kind of psychological need, such as picking lint off your shirt or playing with your hair.
Is the study of touch, and its rules vary considerably across cultures.
The study of space and it too is culturally regulated.
Is reserved for those closest to us such as family, close friends, and an emotional situation. Its distance is zero to 18 inches.
Is reserved for closer friends, some acquaintances, and colleagues. Its distance is eighteen to forty-eight inches.
Is what we typically find at a larger event such as a party, and its distance is forty-eight inches to twelve feet.
The distance of twelve feet or more. When any of these zones is violated, anxiety or discomfort can result.

Are the space we claim and to which we become emotionally attached along with other members of our communities. Territory and identity are interconnected concepts because of the amount of time, effort, emotion, and self-worth that is invested in what we claim as our primary territories.

Can be defined as the expectation of space around you in an empty elevator or movie theater. How do you feel when someone sits right next to you on a park bench, when there are many other park benches free?

Refers to the belief that a person's culture (his 'in-group' culture) is much better than any other group's culture (an 'out-group' culture), and the tendency is for that person to judge any 'out group' culture by using the norms of his 'in-group' culture.

Are the main barriers to intercultural communication. The negative characteristics attributed to one group can cause beliefs and feelings that lead to biases and discrimination against that group. The discriminated group often suffers from being rejected and avoided in cross-cultural interactions.

Are often generalized negative traits assigned to a group of people (eg, race, nationality, religion, social class, sexual orientation, age, gender) even if these traits may only reflect a selected few of the group.

An offshoot of stereotypes, is an unfair thought, belief, or feeling of dislike for a person or group because of race, nationality, gender, sexual orientation, age, religion, and so on. It is a negative preconceived opinion held by one group toward members of another group that biases perception and provides a reason for discrimination.

Unreasonable refusal to see cultural differences where they exist. This happens when members of one group assume that all groups behave the same way they do, that what is true to their culture is also true to all other cultures. This results in insensitivity to cultural differences.

Is the fear or apprehension associated with either real or anticipated communication with people from another cultural group. The fear is often caused by differences in language ability, verbal and nonverbal communication styles, and expression of emotions.
Is knowing that there are multiple different cultures-based on religion, ethnicity, nationality, and other factors that have different attitudes and outlooks.
Involves accepting those differences without insisting your own culture is better, or that everyone should do it your way.

Refers to the aim of understanding and taking account of the societal and cultural factors involved in gender-based exclusion and discrimination in the most diverse spheres of public and private life. It focuses mainly on instances of structural disadvantage in the positions and roles of women.

Is the realization of gender equality in written and spoken language. Gender equality in language is attained when women and men and those who do not conform to the binary gender system are made visible and addressed in language as persons of equal value, dignity, integrity and respect.
Means usage of certain words which underline stereotypic gendered attributes. (Women are caretakers, gentle and emotional, while men are achievers, strong and logical).
Is a term used to describe a language, policies, or measures that are intended to avoid offense or disadvantage to members of groups in society.
It stands for the localized varieties of English as they are used or spoken in certain areas.
It covers the native English-speaking countries.
It comprises the former colonies.
Are affected by the widespread use of English as a Global languagean important language in business, science, technology and education.

This is the informal language between friends and peers, which uses slang, vulgarities, and colloquialisms.
This is the private, intimaate language reserved for family members or intimate people.

questions.question: (first attested 1751)  a kind of banana plant, Musa textilis, native to the Philippines, the petioles of which yield a strong fiber; the fiber itself, used for making paper, ropes, matting, etc.; Manila hemp.
(1885)  A bivalve mollusk, of great size, the Giant Clam (Tridacna gigas) of the Indian and China seas.
(1898)  A diminutive black buffalo, Bubalus mindorensis, peculiar to the island Mindoro, in the Philippines.
(1876)  an anonaceous tree (Canangium odoratum) of Malaysia, the Philippines, etc., with fragrant greenish-yellow flowers from which a perfume is distilled; hence, the perfume itself.

(1984)  a carton shipped or brought to the Philippines from another country by a Filipino who has been living overseas, typically containing items such as food, clothing, toys, and household products.
(1840)  a village, suburb, or other demarcated neighborhood; a small territorial and administrative district forming the most local level of government; from Tagalog.
(1965)  a group of friends; from Tagalog, ultimately from Spanish barcada boat-load.
(1929)  a social event honoring someone who is about to depart on a journey or leave an organization; a going-away party; a blend of Spanish and English.
(1903)  criminal deception, fraud; dishonest dealing; from Spanish.
(2002)  a soft case in which a womans toiletries and cosmetics are stored; blend of Tagalog and English.
(1910)  a yeast-raised bread roll made of flour, eggs, sugar and salt, widely consumed in the Philippines, especially for breakfast, partly from Tagalog, partly from Spanish.
(1933)  a gift or souvenir given to a friend or relative by a person who has returned from a trip or arrived for a visit; from Tagalog.
(1925)  a small neighborhood store selling a variety of goods; blend of Tagalog and English.
(1987)  a dish consisting of chopped pork, onions, and chilies; from Kapampangan.

(1941)  a buyer or seller involved in an arrangement whereby a customer regularly purchases products or services from the same provider in exchange for favorable treatment; also the arrangement itself; from Tagalog.
(1918)  a member of the same graduation class as another; a classmate; formed by combining batch, n. with mate, n.
(1987)  Kaniya-kaniyang bayad, lit. each one pays their own, used esp. to indicate that the cost of a meal is to be shared.
(1972)  a beauty treatment comprising both a manicure and a pedicure; formed by clipping and blending the words manicure, n. and pedicure, n.
(1840)  a person who is a likely or confirmed candidate for president; formed by adding the able suffix to president.
(1945)  a person who steals a motor vehicle; a car thief; formed following the model of kidnapper
(1886)  a toilet; an old-fashioned American euphemism that continues to be widely used in the Philippines.
(1997)  angry, agitated (e.g., I am so high blood because of this traffic jam!); use of a noun phrase as an adjective.
(1993)  to alight from a vehicle; to get off a bus, train, etc., esp. at a specified stop; a translation of the Filipino verb bumaba.
(1980)  to apprehend and execute (a suspected criminal) without trial; complete semantic change from the original English meaning to rescue

= Latin for 'citizen'.

The politics of citizenship emerge essentially
Crucial to the nature of citizenship (ex: civil rights, political rights, and social rights).
Duties do not necessarily mean that there must be corresponding rights (and vice versa).
Aristotle argues that citizenship was always primarily about participation, that is, about empowerment to
s understood as the enjoyment of basic rights and entitlements, the idea of transnational or global citizenship seems generally more plausible.
It is the values inherent in these two communities coming together within an individual that I believe constitutes global citizenship.
Relates to the world AS A WHOLE (regardless ofational boundaries).

Refers to the social and cultural aspects of global change; a reclaiming of both global and local identity away from the false barriers imposed by the political and economic aspects of the modern system.
It mainly serves the interests of transnational corporations and monetary institutions like the World Bank that work in collaboration with the most powerful economies in the world (Demaine, 2002).

Social movements, non-government organizations, and people who are active in grassroots initiatives and community-based movements. These people want to open up spaces for community building and meaningful participation in democracies.
An algorithm must terminate after a finite number of steps.
Algorithm is precisely defined.
Domain of the algorithm which could be zero or more quantities.

Ensured if all the operations in the algorithm are sufficiently basic that they can, in principle, be done exactly and in finite time by a person using paper and pen.

questions.question: Greatest integer less than or equal to x (x is any real  number).
Smallest integer greater than or equal to x
Given any two real numbers x and y.
Quantifies the amount of time taken by an algorithm to run as a function of the length of the input.

Amount of time spent in executing instructions of a given akgorithm. Notation: T(n). Several factors: input size, instruction type, machine speed, quality of source of the algorithm implementation, quality of the machine code generated from the source code by the computer.
Quantifies the amount of space or memory taken by an algorithm to run as a function of the lenght of the input.

A method of analyzing an algorithm by determining: the number of times eacch program line runs, time required to execute each line, no. of times each procedures were called, total space alocated to run the program, etc.
The analysis solely on the way algorithms solve problems.
What the designer can control.

It provides us with dynamic arrays in java. It is similar to vector in C++.

The process of understanding and specifying in detail what an information system should do
The process of specifying in detail how the parts an information system should be implemented. Create a technical solution that satisfies the functional requirements for the system.
Is a step by step process for developing high quality information system.
A group of interralated components that function together to achieve a desired result.
A system that is part of a larger system.
A larger system that contains other systems.
Deviding a system into components based on subsystems that in turn are further divided into subsystems.

A arrangement of people, data, process and information technology that interact to collect, process, store and procuide provide as output the information needed to support an organization. Capture and manage data to provide useful information that supports an organization, employees, customers, suppliers and partners.
A contemporary term that describes the combination of computer technology with telecommunications technology such as data, image, and voice networks)
A technical specialist who translates system users business requirements and constraints into technical solutions.
A technical specialist who construct information systems and components based on the design specifications generated by system designers.
A specialist who studies the problem and needs of an organization to determine thow people, data, process and IT can best accomplish improvements for the business.
Includes the responsibilities of both the computer programmer and the system analyst.
Focuses on only the nontechnical aspects of systems analysis and design.

A system analysts, system desinger, system builder who sells his or her experties and experience to other businesses to help those business pruchase, develop or integrate their information systems solutions; may be affiliated with a consulting or services organization

An experienced professional who accepts responsibility fo plannig monitoring and controlling projects with respect to budget, schedule deliverables, customer satisfaction technical standards and quality.
It is used to represent a company;s operations and information needs. It requires business profile and a series of models that document various business processes.
Defines a company's overall functions, processes, organization, products, services, customers, suppliers, competitors, contraints, and future direction.
Graphically repressent business functions that consist of business processes, such as sales, accounting, and pruchasing, which peform specific tasks.
A technique that seeks to alter the nature of the work done in a business function, with the objective of radically improving performance. A strategy to simplify operations or reduce cost.
It is the physical layer of the information system.
It controls the hardware and software environment and includes the operating software.
It consists of programs that process data to produce information.
Is is stored in files and databases is a vital component of every system.
Defined tha task tha must be performed by users, managers, and IS staff.
Who use the system are called users, and end users.
An IS that captures and process data about the transactions that affect organization.
An IS that provides for management oriented reporting based on transaction processing system and operations of an organization.
An IS that helps to identify decision making opportunities or provides infomration to help make decisions.
An IS that supports planning and assessment needs of executive managers.

An IS that captures the experties of workers and then simulates that experties to the benefit of non expert. It simulate human reasoning by combining a knowledge base with inference rules that determine how the knowledge is applied.

An IS that supports wide range of business office activities for improved work flow between workers. It helps employees create and share documents and maintain information about work schedules, appointments and meetings.
Any person who has interest in an existing or proposed infomration system. They may include technical workers and non technical workers. Internal or external workers.
An information system sponsor and executive advocate, usually reponsible for funding the project of developing, operating, and maintainnig the information system.
A customer who will use or is affected by an information system on a regular basis-capturing, validating, entering, reponding to, storing, and exchaging data and information.
Users: Clerical and Service workers, Technical and professional Staff, Supervisors, middle managers, and executive managers.
Users: Customers, Suppliers, Partners, Employees
Users who are not physically located on the premises but who still requires access to information systems.
User whose location is constantly changing but who requires access to information systems from any location.
Desing database and coordinate changes to corporate database.
Design, install, configure, optimize local and wide.
Design Websites
Design and construct easy to use user interface.
Develops operating system sofware's utilities, and services.
Code and maintain websites
(industrial) Companies that manufacture and sell goods
Companies that mainly offer information, services, or sell goods made by others.
dot-com (.com)
Develop long range plans called strategic plans that defines company's overall mission and goals.
Provide direction, resources and performance feedback to supervisors and teram leaders.
Oversee operational tasks and people, make necessary decisions and ensure that right tools, materials and training are available.
Include users who rely on transactiopn processing systems to enter and recieve data they need to perform their jobs.
A step by step process for planning creating, testing, and deploying an information system.
To identify problem's nature/scope, goals, schedules and budget.
Preliminary investigation report.
To understood business requirements and build a logical model of the new system.
To create blueprint for the new system that will satisfy all document requirements. Identify all outputs, inputs, files, manual procedures, and application programs.
Construct / deliver information. To deliver a completely functioning and documentad information system.
It staff maintains and enhances the system.
Changes correct errors and adapt to changes in the environment.
Provides new features and benefits.
The result of each phase (end product or deliverable ) flows down into the next phase.
An alternative model where planning, analysis, and design interact. Activities overlap and appear to be done concurrently.
A development approach that complete parts of a system in one or more iterations and puts them into operation for users.
A comprehensive guidelines to follow for completing every activity in the systems development life cycle.
Traditional systems development technique that uses SDLC phases to plan, analyze, design, implement, and support an information system.
Combines data and process (methods) into single entities called onjects. System is a collection of interacting.
A representation of an important aspect of the real world.
A series of formulas that describe technical aspects of a system.
Narrative memos, reports or lists that descibe some aspect of a system.
Diagrams and schematice representations of aspect of a system.
Produces a grapichal representation of a concept or process that a system can analyze, test, and modify.
Describes business functions that an IS must support.
Describes data structure and design
Describes objects which combine data and processes.
Portrays the design which and protocols of telecommunications links.
Describes system logic and processes that programmers use to develo necessary code modules.
A graphical model showing the input, process, output and data storage of data.
A graphical model of the data needed by a system and the relationships among them.
A graphical model used in the object oriented approach to show all of the classes of objects in the system.
Involves the creation of an early working version of the system or its components.
Software support that helps create models or other components required in the project.
It maby in the form of sentences, paragraphs, or words that are all used to communicate with the reader.
Converts images of handwritten or typewritter text into machine-editable text.
Any text that does not have any formatting associated with it. Thet are only printable letters, white spacem and line breaks in this plane text.
This text displayed in specified format that may be qualitative (ex. fontface) and quantitative (ex. color, size).
It supports the use of different font styles, color, and size by using tags such as angled brackets and special characters.
It is the standard file format with the purpose of exchaging documents between different word processors such as Office, WordPerfect and SatrOffice. All word processors suport this format.

It is a group of two or more interconnected computer systems.
It is defined as the interconnection of two or more computers.
A network allows user to share many hardware devices such as printers, modems, fax machines, CD ROM, players and more.
Reduces the cost of software installation, saves space on hard disk.

answers: Communication from one computer to another computer
Exchange of data and information among user via network
Sharing of information over geographically wide areas
enumeration.question: Application of Networking

answers: Helps you to connect with multiple computers together to send and receive information when accesing the network.
Helps you to share printers, scanners, and email.
Helps you to share informtaion at very fast speed.
Electonic communication is more efficient and less expensive than without the network.
enumeration.question: Advantage of Copmuter Network

questions.question: It work as a controller which connects computers, printers, and other hardware devices to a network in a campus or a building. It allows devices on your network to communicate with each other, as well as with other networks. It helps you to share resource and reduce the costing of any organization.

Help you to connect with multiple networks. It enables you to share a single internet connection with multiple devices and saves money. This networking component acts as a dispatcher, which allows you to analyze data sent across a network. It automatically selects the best route for data to travel and send it on its way.
Computers that hold shared programs, files, and the network operating system. Servers allow access to network resources to all the users of the network.

It is a device that splits network connection into multiple computers. It acts a distribution center so whenever a computer requests any information from a computer or from the network it sends the request to the hub through a cable. The hub will receive the request and transmit it to the entire network.
Computer devices which access and uses the network as well as shares network resources. They are also users of the network, as they can send and receive requests from the server.
It is a carrier used to interconnect computers in a network, such as coaxial cable, twisted-pair wire, and optical fiber cable. It is also known as links, channels, or lines.
A data which is shared between the clients such as data files, printer access programs, and email.
It sends, receives data, and controls data flow between the computer and the network.
It helps personal computers to access files, print to a local printer and uses one or more disk and CD drives which are located on the computer.
It is a program which runs on computers and servers. It allows the computers to communicate via network.
It is the set of defined rules that allows two entities to communicate across the network. Some standard protocols used for this purpose are IP, TCP, UDP, FTP, etc.
It is also called as Ethernet or data cable. It is used for connecting a device to the internet.
Every device of the network is associated with a unique device.
It is as a unique identifier for each device on the Internet. Length of the IP address is 32-bits. IPv6 address is 64 bits.
It is a server which translates URL or web addresses into their corresponding IP addresses.
It is known as a physical address is a unique identifier of each host and is associated with the NIC. General length of: 12-digit/ 6 bytes/ 48 bits

It is a logical channel which allows network users to send or receive data to an application. Every host can have multiple applications running. Each of these applications are identified using the port number on which they are running.
